ENG



With his tale of a priest (Aldo Fabrizi) trying to survive in wartime Italy, Roberto Rossellini created the proto-typical piece of neo-realist cinema, an example followed by colleagues including Federico Fellini, who co-wrote this masterpiece.

Never mind the appallingly approximate subtitles (you don't have to be Italian to see how bad they are), marvel instead at the stark imagery that makes use of Rome's war-damaged streetscapes as Rossellini portrays the moral quicksand of Nazi collaboration and gives us one of cinema's first portraits of state-sanctioned torture. Sixty years on, it packs a punch.
